required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: HFNC Flow Titration and Effort of Breathing in the PICU
clinical_study.official_title: High-Flow Nasal Cannula Flow Titration and Effort of Breathing in the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit

brief_summary.textblock: High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) is a method of non-invasive respiratory support used to decrease the effort of breathing (EOB) in patients with a wide variety of respiratory diseases in the pediatric intensive care unit. While its use has shown association with decreased rates of mechanical ventilation, there is a paucity of data examining its direct effect upon objective measurements of EOB. This study will aim to evaluate objective measurements of EOB in response to different levels of HFNC support, characterize the natural course of respiratory diseases treated with HFNC, evaluate changes in EOB secondary to the administration of supplemental medical therapies used in conjunction with HFNC, and compare different physiologic metrics for quantifying EOB in patients on HFNC.

primary_outcome.measure: A relative change in a physiologic metric of effort of breathing

secondary_outcome.measure: An absolute change in a physiologic metric of effort of breathing

arm_group.description: All participants in the study are on high flow nasal cannula (HFNC). The flow rate of the HFNC is adjusted to determine if there exists a change in their effort of breathing.

intervention.description: Measurements of effort of breathing will be obtained at flow rates of 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, and 2.0 L/kg/min. Adequate time will be allowed at each flow rate for stabilization of EOB and flow levels will be trialed in a random order, each being trialed for approximately 5 minutes.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All participants less than or equal to three years old admitted to the PICU placed on high flow nasal cannula will be considered eligible for the study.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Participants will be excluded if they have a corrected gestational age less than 37 weeks or contraindications to nasoesophageal catheter placement (nasopharyngeal or esophageal abnormalities) or RIP bands (abdominal wall defects such as omphalocele). Patients greater than three years of age will be excluded.
